topic.title: String Functions and Operators
topic.shortdesc: This section describes functions and operators for examining and manipulating string values.

body.p: Strings include values of all the types character, character varying, and text. Unless otherwise noted, all of the string functions listed below work on all of these types, but be wary of potential effects of the automatic padding when using the character type. Generally, the functions described here also work on data of non-string types by converting that data to a string representation first. Some functions also exist natively for the bit-string types.

SQL defines some string functions with a special syntax where certain key words rather than commas are used to separate the arguments. Details are in . These functions are also implemented using the regular syntax for function invocation. (See .)

The convert() and pg_client_encoding() functions are classified as STABLE. All of the built-in conversion functions (see) are VOLATILE. STABLE or VOLATILE functions can only be safely executed on the master.

row.entry: Change encoding using specified conversion name. Conversions can be defined by CREATE CONVERSION. Also there are some pre-defined conversion names. See for available conversion names.

entry.codeph: overlay(string placing string from int [for int])

row.entry: Extract substring matching POSIX regular expression. See for more information on pattern matching.
Extract substring matching SQL regular expression. See for more information on pattern matching.
Remove the longest string containing only the characters (a space by default) from the start/end/both ends of the string

body.p: shows usage examples for some of the functions in .

table.title: SQL String Functions and Operators Examples

body.p: Additional string manipulation functions are available and are listed in . Some of them are used internally to implement the SQL-standard string functions listed in .

row.entry: ASCII code of the first byte of the argument
Remove the longest string consisting only of characters in characters (a space by default) from the start and end of string
Character with the given ASCII code
Convert string to dest_encoding. The original encoding is specified by src_encoding. If src_encoding is omitted, database encoding is assumed.
Decode binary data from string previously encoded with encode. Parameter type is same as in encode.
Encode binary data to different representation. Supported types are: base64, hex, escape. Escape merely outputs null bytes as \000 and doubles backslashes.
Convert the first letter of each word to uppercase and the rest to lowercase. Words are sequences of alphanumeric characters separated by non-alphanumeric characters.

entry.codeph: lpad(string text, length int [, fill text])

row.entry: Fill up the string to length length by prepending the characters fill (a space by default). If the string is already longer than length then it is truncated (on the right).
Remove the longest string containing only characters from characters (a space by default) from the start of string
Calculates the MD5 hash of string, returning the result in hexadecimal

Return the given string suitably quoted to be used as an identifier in an SQL statement string. Quotes are added only if necessary (i.e., if the string contains non-identifier characters or would be case-folded). Embedded quotes are properly doubled.
Return the given string suitably quoted to be used as a string literal in an SQL statement string. Embedded single-quotes and backslashes are properly doubled.

entry.codeph: regexp_replace(string text, pattern text, replacement text [,flags text])

row.entry: Replace substring matching POSIX regular expression. See for more information on pattern matching.
Repeat string the specified number of times

entry.codeph: replace(string text, from text, to text)

row.entry: Replace all occurrences in string of substring from with substring to

entry.codeph: rpad(string text, length int [, fill text])

row.entry: Fill up the string to length length by appending the characters fill (a space by default). If the string is already longer than length then it is truncated.
Remove the longest string containing only characters from characters (a space by default) from the end of string

entry.codeph: split_part(string text, delimiter text, field int)

row.entry: Split string on delimiter and return the given field (counting from one)
Location of specified substring (same as position(substring in string), but note the reversed argument order)
Extract substring (same as substring(string from from for count))
Convert string to ASCII from another encoding (only supports conversion from LATIN1, LATIN2, LATIN9, and WIN1250 encodings)
Convert number to its equivalent hexadecimal representation

entry.codeph: translate(string text, from text, to text)

row.entry: Any character in string that matches a character in the from set is replaced by the corresponding character in the to set

body.p: shows usage examples for functions in .
The built-in conversion functions convert from a source encoding to a destination encoding. All built-in conversion functions are classified as VOLATILE and should not be executed on segments.

The conversion names follow a standard naming scheme: The official name of the source encoding with all non-alphanumeric characters replaced by underscores followed by _to_ followed by the equally processed destination encoding name. Therefore the names might deviate from the customary encoding names.
